title: ✖️ Prostate Problems: Causes & Solutions For 2025
content:
I know so many men who have prostate problems.

His brother died from prostate cancer.

My uncle on my mom’s side had prostate cancer, but it’s in remission.

Friend’s dad died of prostate cancer a year ago.

My 55-year-old best friend is having prostate surgery because he can hardly pee anymore, and that’s with prostate-shrinking drugs. And he’s a healthy guy.

Simply stated, most men will have prostate problems the longer they live.

You may not die from it, even though prostate cancer is a leading cause of cancer death in men.

However, having prostate problems is going to suck because it’s going to be uncomfortable and painful and also cause sexual problems.

Remember, the prostate interacts when you urinate and ejaculate.

So, you really need to make sure it stays healthy and youthful as long as possible.

So, today you’ll quickly discover:

Symptoms of prostate problems

Causes of prostate growth and cancer

Solutions – both natural and medical

Let’s first talk about prostate growth, which is called BPH – benign prostatic hyperplasia:

Benign because it’s not cancerous

Prostatic means prostate

Hyperplasia means growth or enlargement

By age 50, about 50% of men have some prostate growth, even if there are no symptoms.

Until age 60, about 70% of men have BPH

By age 80, this increases to 80% of men

BPH is NOT cancer and doesn’t necessarily increase cancer risk

The size of the enlargement doesn’t always correlate with symptom severity

Now, how do you know if you have prostate cancer and not BPH or prostate growth?

Getting a blood test checking for your PSA levels is important and something to keep an eye on.

If it’s high or all of a sudden your PSA levels shoot up, then I’m sure your doctor will dig deeper into things and see what the cause could be. Even a simple infection can temporarily raise PSA levels.

So, always have your doctor do a PSA blood test, especially if you’re over the age of 40.

Medical journals will list the following symptoms linked to prostate growth:

Urinary frequency (going more than 8 times daily)

Sudden, strong urges to urinate

Nocturia (waking up more than once nightly to urinate)

Weak urine stream compared to your younger years

Difficulty starting urination (hesitancy)

Starting and stopping mid-stream (intermittency)

Feeling like you can’t fully empty your bladder

Post-void dribbling (leaking after you think you’re done)

Urgency leakage when you can’t make it to the bathroom

Prostate growth happens for a variety of reasons.

1 – Genetics and Family History

Always play a role, and it can increase your risk. However, my dad’s younger brother died of prostate cancer and yet my dad never had it and he lived longer.

2 – Hormonal Imbalances

DHT is linked to prostate problems. It gets converted from testosterone. Your prostate gland has the highest amount of DHT receptors.

Your skin and scalp also have lots of DHT receptors. Hence, high DHT causes body hair growth and hair loss.

Estrogen is another major contributor to prostate growth AND cancer. It’s probably worse than DHT. Something most experts won’t tell you or know.

Ironically, testosterone is good for the prostate.

However, as we age, testosterone levels drop and get converted more into DHT and Estrogen. This means lower testosterone and high “negative” hormones.

Low testosterone, combined with higher DHT and Estrogen, is a primary cause of prostate growth.

Low levels of Vitamin D are linked to prostate growth. Vitamin D is not technically a vitamin — it’s a hormone.

Most people, especially men, do NOT have optimal levels.

4 – Chronic Inflammation

Ongoing inflammation in the body contributes to prostate issues.

5 – Metabolic Syndrome

Being unhealthy — high blood pressure, excess body fat, and diabetes — significantly raises the risk. Diabetes alone doubles your risk.

6 – High Stress & Cortisol

Stress elevates cortisol, which puts pressure on the prostate gland and suppresses testosterone while raising inflammation and blood sugar.

Keep body fat low. High body fat increases estrogen.

Having a waist circumference over 40 inches increases risk by 50%.

Just 2 hours of walking weekly reduces BPH risk by 30%

Exercising 6x weekly reduces risk by 50%

3 – Improve Your Diet

Limit high-fat red meat

Eat 4+ servings of vegetables daily

Include lycopene-rich foods like tomatoes and watermelon

Use extra virgin olive oil and fish oil

4 – Manage Chronic Conditions

Control diabetes, blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol

Lower inflammation and stress

5 – Take Supplements or Medication

Drugs like Finasteride (Propecia/Proscar) work well for shrinking the prostate but may cause erectile problems. They also increase estrogen.

Saw Palmetto is a natural alternative. It works to lower DHT and estrogen with fewer side effects.

Zinc with copper also helps lower DHT, improve libido, and support prostate health with no sexual side effects.

Lose fat and take supplements like DIM, Zinc, and Vitamin D.

Use anti-inflammatory herbs like curcumin, ginger, and boswellia extract.

Prescription option: Flomax — an alpha-blocker that relaxes prostate and bladder muscles. It’s effective and generally well-tolerated.

Increase Testosterone

Boosting testosterone naturally while lowering DHT and estrogen can dramatically improve prostate health, libido, and erections.

Testosterone injections (TRT) can worsen prostate issues due to high DHT and estrogen conversion, requiring additional meds to manage.

AlphaViril was designed to improve testosterone while controlling DHT and estrogen — good for your hormones, erections, libido, and prostate.

I’ve worked with hundreds of men and ALL of them improved their prostate health using these steps.

If you do nothing, your prostate will grow larger and cause more pain, urinary issues, and sexual dysfunction — or worse, cancer.

Take this seriously. Take action now. Don’t just read — do something about it today.

title: Women Are Lowering Your Testosterone In 2025 & How To Fix It
content:
Today I’ve got a controversial topic — do women lower your testosterone levels?

This came up after I received a long email from a subscriber, and I want to share that story and explore the science and personal experience behind it.

A Real Story from a Viewer

Here’s the message I received:

“Hey doc, I think being in a relationship is killing my testosterone. I’m not motivated like I used to be and my sex drive is in the toilet.

About two years ago, I did a blood test and my testosterone level was 812 — which I think is pretty good.

Then I met my girlfriend. A year later, I did another blood test and it dropped to 371. Nothing else changed in my life other than having a girlfriend.

Recently, I started taking AlphaViril and 6 months later, my testosterone increased to 724. I feel better, but still not as good as I was before my girlfriend. Could being in a relationship really lower my testosterone? Should I break up with her?”

Initial Reactions & What the Research Says

Yes — being in a relationship can lower testosterone levels.

But it’s not that women themselves are the problem. This is a nuanced issue involving emotions, stress, lifestyle, and brain chemistry.

During the early stages of dating, testosterone and dopamine levels are high — you’re pursuing, hunting, energized.

Over time, once your emotional needs are met, things become stable and sexually routine. Dopamine drops, and so does testosterone.

Toxic Relationships and Hormonal Health

This subscriber didn’t mention the quality of his relationship. And that’s important.

If you’re in a toxic relationship — constantly criticized, manipulated, belittled — it’s like emotional castration.

This causes a drop in self-esteem and can lead to increased cortisol, the real enemy of testosterone. That’s right — the opposite hormone of testosterone isn’t estrogen, it’s cortisol. When cortisol rises, testosterone falls.

How Stress Kills Testosterone

Any long-term stress increases cortisol and adrenaline, which decreases testosterone. Whether it’s from:

Money or career problems

Relationship conflict

… Chronic stress is a major testosterone killer.

Scientific Studies on Relationships & Testosterone

Studies show that men in committed romantic relationships have approximately 20–21% lower testosterone levels than single men.

Another study found that the longer a man is in a relationship, the lower his testosterone.

Some researchers argue this is a good thing — it may reflect relationship satisfaction.

But for many men, low testosterone means a drop in sex drive, energy, and self-confidence.

What Happens When Testosterone Drops?

As testosterone falls, so does drive, not just sexually, but in all areas of life.

You become apathetic. Stop taking action. You stop feeling like a man.

Lower testosterone can turn into a cycle of inaction and low self-worth. And if you’re the type of person who’s a “nice guy,” being in a toxic relationship can amplify these effects — especially if you’re being taken for granted or disrespected.

A Personal Story & Observation

I dated a woman years ago who respected her mom but not her dad.

Her mom was “the boss,” and her dad was “a potato.” Over time, her mom had broken him down emotionally. He eventually gave up and stopped trying. I’ve seen this in many relationships, and I’ve experienced it myself.

If you’re constantly accommodating and passive, you’ll lose your partner’s respect. And when respect is lost, attraction follows.

The Long-Term Cost of Staying in a Toxic Relationship

If you’re in a toxic relationship, you have two choices:

Fix it with counseling if it’s possible.

Get out before it damages your health even further.

People rarely change. If things are bad now, they often get worse.

Don’t let yourself be the person who sacrifices their health and happiness trying to “make it work” when it’s clearly harmful.

If you’re in a positive, respectful relationship, awesome — communicate that appreciation. But regardless of your relationship status, the real key is to:

Increase testosterone

Decrease stress and cortisol

Because once your hormones are optimized, your energy, confidence, and drive will return. Life will feel exciting again. And you’ll start making better decisions — for your body, your mind, and your relationships.

So take action today.

And if you’re in a toxic situation, don’t delay: Fix it or move on.

You’re too important to waste your life in stress and hormonal imbalance.

title: 👍 8 Best Erectile Dysfunction (ED) Treatments In 2025
content:
If you’re dealing with erectile dysfunction, you’re not broken — and you’re definitely not alone.

Today, I’m going to show you how to fix it with the 8 best, clinically proven methods… no matter how bad your situation is.

I’ve personally dealt with erectile problems at various times in my life, so I know how it can kill your confidence and cause problems in your relationship.

Also, Erectile dysfunction isn’t just a bedroom problem. It’s a warning sign your body is trying to send you, which is also negatively affecting your heart and brain.

Why Does Erectile Dysfunction Happen?

First, it’s important to understand: Erectile dysfunction isn’t just about blood flow — although that’s a big part of it.

Low testosterone & hormonal imbalances

Stress – emotional and/or physical

Lack of specific enzymes

Side effects from common medications & drugs

Or even a combination of the above. That’s why there’s no ‘one-size-fits-all’ solution.

8 Best Clinically Proven Solutions For Erectile Dysfunction

Most people have heard of these drugs, such as Viagra and Cialis. PDE5 inhibitors block the PDE5 enzyme, relaxing blood vessels and increasing blood flow.

Originally developed for blood pressure, Sildenafil (Viagra’s active ingredient) had an unexpected benefit — erections.

They work in about 50% of users, usually younger men with better testosterone levels. However, they don’t fix the root cause and become less effective over time.

2 – Testosterone Therapy

TRT (Testosterone Replacement Therapy) can help men with clinically low testosterone. It’s available via injections, gels, or pills.

If done right, TRT can be amazing. If done wrong, it can cause side effects like acne, hair loss, prostate problems, testicle shrinkage, and mood swings.

TRT is a lifelong commitment and should only be used after trying natural methods first.

3 – Life Improvements

Even with good hormone levels, stress, poor sleep, and emotional issues can destroy your sex drive and erections.

Fix your health, improve your diet, reduce stress, and get quality sleep.

These basics are often overlooked but are crucial for sexual performance.

Most supplements don’t work — unless you use the right ingredients, dosage, and extract.

AlphaViril – A proven testosterone booster that also helps balance dopamine, estrogen, DHT, and cortisol.

L-citrulline – Improves nitric oxide. Take 3–5g before sex (powder is more cost-effective).

5 – Shockwave Therapy

Low-intensity extracorporeal shockwave therapy uses sound waves to stimulate blood vessel growth in the penis.

It’s still new but shows promising results for vascular-related ED. Some discomfort is expected, but it’s temporary.

6 – Penile Injections

Trimix injections (papaverine, phentolamine, and prostaglandin E1) are used in extreme cases.

They work instantly but involve injecting directly into the penis. Effective, but should be a last resort and does NOT treat the root cause.

7 – Vacuum Erection Devices (Penis Pumps)

A mechanical way to draw blood into the penis. Prescribed by doctors and available online. Safe and non-invasive.

Especially effective when combined with other therapies. I’ll cover the best pumps in a future video.

8 – Penile Implants (Surgery)

For severe, irreversible ED, implants may be the final option. A mechanical device is surgically inserted to trigger erections on demand.

High risk and permanent — only consider after trying everything else.

If you have erectile dysfunction, the good news is there are effective treatments — but first, you must figure out why it’s happening.

Is it physical? Hormonal? Emotional? Most likely, it’s a mix of all three.

The best approach is a combination — treat the root cause, improve your lifestyle, and support your body with the right supplements or therapies.

Millions of men deal with ED.

You’re not alone. But you do need to take action today to get your confidence, vitality, and erections back.

content:
Even though you hear how awesome a drug like Viagra is for erections, you don’t hear about all the problems, and one of them is that Viagra doesn’t work for almost 50% of users.

Clinical studies show that up to 35% of users are non-responders. That means even at the highest dose of 100 mg, a “satisfactory erection is not achieved”.

This typically has to do with genetics or hormonal problems.

On top of the 35%, there’s another 15%–20% of users who don’t respond because of some pre-existing health problem, such as diabetes, poor blood flow, blood pressure issues, and so forth.

Then there’s another 10%–15% of users who get too many side effects such as low blood pressure, nasal or eye problems, headaches, rapid heart rate, and so forth.

Now, I just threw a bunch of boring percentages at you.

The bottom line is that Viagra doesn’t work for a lot more people than it does for.

However, let me give you some simple solutions that can improve these numbers while also reducing the negative side effects.

First and foremost, the higher your testosterone levels, the better Viagra will work for you.

Testosterone improves Nitric Oxide (NO) levels, which is how Viagra works.

Testosterone boosts Dopamine, which also supports stronger erections.

This is why Viagra works much better in younger men with high testosterone levels than in older guys with low testosterone. It’s a sad irony — the guys who don’t need it, it works better for them than the guys who do.

The good news is that you can naturally increase testosterone levels, which will make Viagra work better even at a lower dose.

Start with a low dose to see how you respond:

Start with 25 mg a couple of times

If that doesn’t work, try 50 mg

If still no result, then go to 100 mg

3. How You Take It Matters

If taking it orally, drink it with water on an empty stomach — at least 2 hours after a meal or 1 hour before eating.

Taking it with food dramatically lowers its effectiveness.

Better method: Take it sublingually (under your tongue):

Let it dissolve under your tongue for 5–10 minutes

Then wash it down with a glass of water

You can also take it as a suppository (in your rectum) for fast absorption, but sublingual is easier and more effective for most people.

Viagra has a 4-hour half-life, which means half of the drug is still in your system after 4 hours.

It takes 20–60 minutes to hit peak effectiveness once consumed. This varies depending on:

Sublingual vs oral intake

For some people, it can take up to 2 hours to really kick in. Be patient.

5. Avoid These Mistakes

Remember: Viagra doesn’t cause an erection on its own. You still need to get aroused.

So avoid anything that kills arousal or blood flow:

Prescription meds known to cause ED

If you already have erection issues AND low testosterone, don’t make it worse by taking substances that cause erectile problems.

6. Supplements That Can Help

This amino acid boosts nitric oxide levels. Take 5 grams about 30 minutes before sex.

Tip: Use powder form — it’s cheaper and faster absorbing than pills.

As mentioned earlier, testosterone is essential for Viagra to work. A quality testosterone booster is a must.

Improving overall circulation and vascular health helps maximize performance. Certain supplements can enhance blood flow to the muscles — including your penis.

If you’ve done everything mentioned above — optimized hormones, increased testosterone, and taken Viagra the right way — and it still doesn’t work…

Don’t worry — there are other options.

I’ll be doing an article soon covering these alternatives.

title: 🌜Nighttime Peeing (Nocturia) - 8 Ways To Stop It In 2025
content:
Waking up multiple times at night to urinate (nocturia) can disrupt sleep, increase stress hormones, decrease testosterone, and significantly lower the quality of life.

Unfortunately, it’s often caused by aging and some lesser-known hormonal changes — and NO, not the ones you’ve likely heard about in the past.

Here’s a quick guide on why it happens and how to minimize it.

1. Control Your Liquids

Start the day with plenty of water and salt.

Then, slowly reduce your liquid intake throughout the day and avoid any liquids 2–3 hours before bed.

The more water you drink, the more salt you need to help absorb it — especially as we get older and have lower hormone levels.

Certain compounds act as diuretics — meaning they increase urination. This includes:

Potassium supplements

Dandelion extract, parsley, Uva Ursi

Try to limit or eliminate them close to bedtime.

3. Prostate Enlargement & Nocturia

As men age, their prostate naturally grows due to hormonal imbalances and aging itself.

Get a blood test to check your PSA levels and do a prostate exam to ensure everything is okay.

Prostate growth happens due to low testosterone and higher levels of estrogen and DHT.

You can try natural ways to optimize your hormones and increase testosterone levels using herbs and minerals.

You can also consider medications like Finasteride and Flomax, but they may have side effects like erectile dysfunction.

4. Decline in Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH / Vasopressin)

ADH helps the body retain water at night. This hormone is high in children and young people but declines with age, causing increased nighttime urination.

Most experts never mention this!

Lowering cortisol can help increase ADH and improve sleep quality.

There’s also a prescription option called Desmopressin, a synthetic ADH, used for severe nocturia.

5. Increase Sodium Intake

I already mentioned how important salt is.

When we’re younger, higher sex and growth hormones help our bodies retain water naturally.

As we age, we need to add more salt to help absorb water or else we just pee it all out.

6. Manage Blood Sugar

High blood sugar and insulin levels increase urination. It’s a common symptom of diabetes.

Check your blood sugar and A1C levels in a blood test. Also, reduce sugar in your diet to support stable blood sugar.

7. Kidney Issues & Nocturia

Fluid retention during the day can shift to nighttime urination if your kidneys are processing it then.

Get your creatinine and cystatin C levels checked in a blood test to assess kidney function.

Dehydration and thick blood stress your kidneys. That’s why staying well-hydrated during the day is so important.

8. Bladder Training & Pelvic Floor Exercises

Strengthen your pelvic muscles with Kegel exercises to improve bladder control.

One of my favorite tips: delay urination slightly during the day to build bladder capacity.

As the day progresses, try to hold your urine a little longer (without hurting yourself). This starts to train your bladder to hold more, reducing the urgency and frequency at night.

Don’t drink liquids too close to bedtime

Add more salt to help absorb liquids

Avoid alcohol, coffee, and tea near bedtime

Do blood tests for kidneys, blood sugar, and prostate health

Optimize your hormones: increase testosterone, reduce estrogen, DHT, and cortisol

title: How Big Is Her Vagina? Surprising Scientific Facts For 2025
content:
“Dr. Sam – this is going to be a weird question, but how big or deep is the Vagina? I ask because I did a Google search and found it’s not too deep, like 4 inches. Yet, how does an average penis go all the way in, let alone the big 10 inch porn penis? I know, this is a silly question, but I thought I’d ask because I’m totally confused. Thanks”

Why Size Of Vagina Matters Too

You make some interesting points. More so, most people will talk about the size of the penis – how long or thick or big or small.

Yet, rarely does anyone talk about the size of the vagina, which is also important especially when it comes to understanding sexual compatibility.

Average Vagina Length & Width

Multple studies have shown that the average length or depth of the vagina is about 3.5–4 inches or 9–10 cm.

Now, some are shorter, about 2.5 inches or 6 cm. While some are longer, about 5 inches or 12 cm.

As far as the width of the vagina, the range is between 2.5–5 inches or 6–12 cm.

I’ll talk about the average penis size in a minute.

Vaginal Arousal Increases Size

Now, these numbers change and grow when she’s aroused and turned on.

The cervix pulls up and back, adding 1–2 inches to vaginal length.

There’s also additional tissue relaxation, expansion, and lubrication for greater flexibility and easier penetration.

So, if the average vagina is up to 4 inches, plus another 2 inches when she’s aroused, that comes to about 6 inches deep as a potential maximum – right?

You Don’t Need a Huge Penis to Satisfy Her

So what does this mean?…

That you don’t need a huge penis to satisfy a woman. In fact, most of the sensitivity is in the first 2–3 inches of the vagina.

That’s why your finger can be a powerful tool.

I mention this because I know many guys are insecure about the size of your penis. So, I’m just letting you know, that you don’t need a huge, 8–10 inch porn penis to satisfy her…

And honestly, most women don’t want a huge penis.

Average Man’s Penis Size

But let’s quickly talk about the average penis size.

The average erect penis length worldwide is approximately 5.4 inches.

95% of men have erect penises ranging from 4.2 to 6.7 inches.

99.7% of men have erect penises shorter than 7.3 inches.

This means that the vast majority of men fall within a relatively narrow range, and those with lengths over 7 inches are statistically uncommon and very rare.

So if you have a penis over 8 inches, you are about 0.3% of the population.

The next time you watch porn and see a huge dick, just know that it’s the rare exception and not the norm.

That’s why he is in porn.

So, please stop comparing yourself to these rare exceptions.

Just as the avid basketball player doesn’t compare himself to Michael Jordan. Or the guy lifting weights shouldn’t compare himself to a professional bodybuilder.

These are rare, genetic freaks.

Additionally, the next time you hear a girl saying how she likes a big penis or her ex-boyfriend had this huge dick or something similar, just know that she’s either lying or she can’t measure.

However, if you do want to increase the size of your penis for whatever reason — the length or girth or both — I have a free guide about this topic.

It’s not just about growing your penis, it’s also about improving the health of your penis, erection quality, and so forth.

I’ll give you the link to that at the end of this video.

Common Misconceptions

Let me also quickly talk about some common misconceptions.

Having more sexual partners does NOT change the vaginal size or length. Again, it’s mostly genetics.

If a woman’s vagina feels looser over time, possibly because she’s had babies, or age — that’s caused by neurological conditions or having less collagen and usually, having a weak pelvic floor.

And to help fix that and tighten the vagina, doing Kegel exercises will help. In fact, Kegel exercises are also very helpful for men for improving erections.

How Porn Creates Size Illusions

And finally to address your other question about how a porn star with a huge 8–10 inch penis can penetrate a vagina that can only go 6–7 inches maximum depth…

Well, certain angles will give the illusion that the penis is all the way in. Such as doggie style because her ass is in the way.

Also, if you pay close attention, the guy is not putting his penis all the way in to the base. He’s penetrating as far as he can, but it’ll be around 6–7 inches, depending on the girl.

It’s rarely “balls deep”. Granted, there are some women who can take it all. But that’s just their genetics. Most women can’t.

Lastly, it’s porn and these people are acting. They may pretend to be enjoying it, but they are in a bit of pain and discomfort.

I used to consult porn guys years ago and they would tell me that the girls would take painkillers if the guy was really big.

So in summary, the vagina is not as big as you think. The average penis is fine for the average vagina.

So if you’re a man watching this, try not to feel so insecure about the size of your penis.

However, I do know that some guys do want a larger, thicker, and harder penis and I created a free guide for that.

title: ☠️ Top 7 Testosterone Killers In Your Home (2025 )
content:
If you’ve been reading my blog for any length of time, you know that genetics aside, I am a firm believer that the way you look and feel, is very dependent on your hormones.

Unfortunately, there are many factors that can negatively affect your hormones – food, exercise, stress, supplements, and today’s topic – 7 things in your home, that are lowering and killing your testosterone levels and at the same time, increasing your negative, “anti-testosterone” hormones.

This is a problem for both men and women, but much more so for men because they are very dependent on testosterone.

Basically, with all of these testosterone killers in your home, the end result is that you look and feel older.

You’re going to lose your sex drive, lose muscle size and strength, get fatter, feel depressed, and accelerate the aging process!

And it seems that a primary cause of these problems is excess estrogen, which indirectly lowers testosterone. Also, estrogen is the primary cause of both breast AND prostate cancer.

So, it’s a big problem that you want to fix.

Now, your body can create its own estrogen internally (endogenously). However, there are also environmental estrogens, from the outside (exogenously), and that’s what I’m going to quickly discuss today because these you CAN control.

Thus, you should try your best to limit or hopefully eliminate the following 7 testosterone killers in your home.

Otherwise known as BPA, it is probably the most well-known of a family of chemicals used in the production of polycarbonate plastics for its effect on the hardness of plastic. Not only has it been linked to low testosterone levels, but also to erectile dysfunction and cancers, both prostate and breast. You can find it in:

Reusable plastic bottles

Clear, hard plastic items

The lining of food cans

Another large family of chemicals has a weak affinity for estrogen receptors.

They are most present in sun-blocking, SPF-blocking lotions though… and this is where they have the potential to cause more damage because you’ll be applying these sun-blocking lotions all over your body. This is not only a very large surface area, but your skin also absorbs the chemicals quickly.

So if you’re out in the sun, please have a gradual exposure or use a paraben-free lotion. You will find those in a wide variety of products in your medicine cabinet:

Many air fresheners, scented candles, and also other items with the mysterious ingredient “perfume” are actually phthalates, a compound also used to make plastics more flexible.

You can find them in many cosmetics and personal care items as well. Make sure you stay away from:

Non-organic/non-Essential Oil-based scented candles

Most commercial perfumes

Scented bathroom sprays

Aromatic personal care products

They have also been found in a lot of fast-food items

So these 3 are external “xenoestrogens”. There are also food-based ones, which would be internal. The two worst are Soy and Beer.

This is the main food source for massive amounts of phytoestrogens. Many vegans and vegetarians want to compensate for the lack of protein from animal sources by eating more soy, which leads to a host of health issues – one of the worst, in my opinion, being a decrease in thyroid levels.

But suffice it to say that regular consumption of soy, even a large dose of the fermented sources, can have detrimental effects on your testosterone levels. Soy is most commonly found in:

Textured soy protein (TSP) or textured vegetable protein (TVP)

Hops found in beer are actually a rich source of phytoestrogens, and even beer on the weekends does decrease testosterone levels. So regular drinking or large amounts have effects on your androgen levels that are compounded by the other health hazards that alcohol has.

This is the main antibacterial agent found in antibacterial soap. It and its cousin triclocarban have a testosterone-lowering effect by decreasing the biosynthesis of testosterone.2,3 In fact, it’s also a carcinogen (cancer-causing). It’s so bad that the European Union banned this chemical in 2010, and so has the state of Minnesota, but not the other 49 states.

It should also be noted that they do a poor job of killing bacteria and are partly to blame for the development of new strains of bacteria that are more resistant. You can find it in:

antibacterial soaps and shampoos (Dial, Softsoap, Clearasil…)

skin cleansing wipes (SaniCart)

toothpaste (Colgate Total…)

deodorants (Old Spice, Right Guard…)

shaving gels (Gillette…)

children’s toys (Playskool…)

brake fluids (STP, Valvoline, Pennzoil…)

antibacterial socks (Fruit of the Loom, Dickies…)

These types of chemicals are found most often in sunscreen lotions – something I told people to avoid over 20 years ago, but that’s another topic. Not only do these chemicals lower your testosterone, but they also decrease androgen receptor sensitivity.4 So, that’s doubly bad.

Oh, it also happens to lower thyroid production as well5 – so now you’ll be losing muscle AND getting fatter at the same time.

Speaking of getting fat, these chemicals ALSO increase estradiol (estrogen) levels in men.6

Unfortunately, there are a lot of other chemicals found in your home that kill your testosterone levels, while also increasing negative estrogen levels. I just wanted to list some of the most common and potent.

There are also environmental ones, such as most herbicides, pesticides, and insecticides. But, I’ll discuss that another day.

My suggestion here is to reread this blog and go through your home and eliminate these types of products and ingredients. As I said, there are more – but this is a good start.

Try your best to eat natural, organically grown foods.

Then, you’ll need to reverse the damage by stimulating your body to produce more testosterone, while reducing and eliminating excess estrogen levels – in addition to other “testosterone-killing” hormones.

And for that, I suggest you click on this special link and discover a proven formula for naturally boosting your testosterone levels, and increasing your libido and muscle size.

title: ❓ Why Do Erectile Problems Happen During Sex? Tips For 2025!
content:
It’s 2025 and I recently got a question from a subscriber that’s extremely common — and something I’ve personally experienced myself, especially when I was younger.

“Dr. Sam – I’m having problems during sex. When it’s time to get intimate, I lose my erection. Or, sometimes during sex, I go limp. I don’t have problems when I masturbate. This is happening mainly around sex and I’m feeling really embarrassed about it. I’m sure she’s going to break up with me. Any suggestions?”

What you’re describing is called performance anxiety.

And even though most guys will lie and pretend it never happens to them — trust me, it’s very common. You’re not alone, and there’s nothing wrong with you.

Why Does Performance Anxiety Happen?

This issue tends to show up in younger men or in new relationships, when confidence is low and insecurity is high — even if it’s subconscious.

It could be triggered by:

Past negative sexual experiences

Comments from your partner that caused self-doubt

Unrealistic expectations from porn or comparisons with her past partners

Worrying about your penis size or performance ability

Stress from unrelated issues like work, finances, or health

The fear of “failing” again based on a previous limp moment

What happens next is your body enters a stress response — your heart rate increases, your body releases cortisol and adrenal hormones, and blood flow to your penis decreases.

Your Brain Is Your Greatest Sex Organ

Remember: relaxation = erections.

The parasympathetic nervous system promotes erections, while the sympathetic nervous system (the stress response) shuts them down.

If you’re thinking negative thoughts, even subconsciously, your body responds by reducing sexual function.

You’re literally stressing yourself out of an erection.

Here are several strategies to reduce performance anxiety and improve your ability to perform — physically and mentally.

1. Recognize It’s Normal

This happens to a lot of men. It’s not about masculinity or attraction — it’s about your mindset and nervous system.

2. Practice Mindfulness During Intimacy

Stay in the moment. Don’t let your mind race with fear or past experiences.

Focus on physical sensations, her reactions, and your own pleasure

When your mind wanders, gently bring it back to the present (yes, it takes practice)

This is especially helpful if you have ADHD or overactive thoughts — like I do.

But the more you practice, the easier it gets.

3. Communicate With Your Partner

Most women will appreciate your vulnerability and will NOT take it personally — especially if you’re open about what you’re feeling.

Open communication reduces pressure and builds trust and connection.

4. Remove the Pressure to Perform

Reframe sex as an opportunity for connection and mutual pleasure, not a performance test.

Focus more on foreplay, kissing, touching, and massaging her

Build anticipation and intimacy without rushing into penetration

Women usually don’t want to go “right into sex” anyway — slow it down

5. Practice Relaxation Techniques

Before intimacy, activate your parasympathetic nervous system with relaxation techniques:

Try deep breathing: Inhale for 3 seconds, exhale for 6 seconds (longer exhale = relaxation)

Use progressive muscle relaxation or meditation to calm your mind and body

6. Try the Sensate Focus Approach

This involves gradually increasing intimacy without focusing on sex. Start with non-genital touch and slowly move forward as comfort builds.

No pressure = less anxiety = better performance.

7. Avoid Alcohol & Substances

Alcohol and weed might seem to help nerves, but they impair erectile function and dull physical sensitivity.

8. Be Patient With Yourself

Recovery takes time. Each positive experience builds confidence for the next one.

Remember: what you focus on expands.

If you focus on what could go wrong, your body will respond accordingly.

If you focus on pleasure, connection, and enjoying the moment, you’ll stay relaxed — and your erection will follow.

I’ve posted links to my favorite ways to:

Increase libido and sex drive

Boost testosterone and dopamine

Improve blood flow for harder, longer-lasting erections

These strategies give you the physical edge so you can feel more confident and reduce performance anxiety naturally.

Try a few of these, stay consistent, and let me know what works best for you.

title: 🧔Want A Thicker Beard? - 2 Proven Methods For 2025
content:
Today, it’s 2025, and I want to answer a question I’ve gotten many times over the years:

“How do I get a thicker beard?”

Is it hormonal? Is it topical? What actually works?

Even though I don’t have a thick beard myself — and if I did, it would probably be all white at this point — I know a lot of guys today want that rugged, full facial hair look.

So, let’s talk about two simple and proven ways to boost beard growth.

What Really Controls Beard Growth?

Aside from genetics, your ability to grow facial hair comes down to two key hormones:

Dihydrotestosterone (DHT)

DHT is produced when testosterone is converted by the enzyme 5-alpha reductase.

This is the hormone most associated with things like body hair growth, facial hair development, and, unfortunately, hair loss and prostate issues.

Beard Growth vs. Hair Loss: What’s the Deal?

Guys with high DHT are often bald and hairy. That thick hair on your back or shoulders? That’s DHT-driven.

But here’s what’s interesting — some guys have high testosterone and DHT, but still don’t have much body or facial hair.

That’s because it’s not just about hormone levels — it’s about how sensitive your androgen receptors are on the skin.

I’ve seen bodybuilders on steroids with full heads of hair and barely any body hair. That’s due to low skin sensitivity to androgens.

And for some ethnicities, like Asians, even higher hormone levels may not translate into visible hair growth because of this same receptor resistance.

Step 1: Optimize Your Testosterone Levels Naturally

The first and most important step is to optimize your testosterone and DHT levels naturally.

Higher testosterone leads to higher DHT, which will stimulate facial hair growth. If you’re struggling to grow a beard, there’s a good chance your testosterone is low or sub-optimal.

I’ve listed my recommended herbs, supplements, and lifestyle strategies to increase testosterone naturally in the description below this video.

Step 2: Use Topical Minoxidil (Rogaine) on Your Beard

Minoxidil, also known as Rogaine, is typically used as a topical treatment for head hair. But it also works for facial hair.

In fact, it was originally an oral blood pressure drug, and doctors noticed one “side effect” — guys started growing back their hair.

Later, they developed a topical version to target scalp hair — but here’s the thing: you can apply the same topical version to your face to help grow your beard.

How to Use Minoxidil on Your Beard

Use the 5% topical solution — available in liquid or foam form

Apply it twice daily — morning and night

Don’t wash it off right away — leave it on your face for full absorption

Be consistent — noticeable results may take 1 to 3 months, and significant results around 6 months

Liquid tends to work better for the face because it rubs in more effectively. Foam is lighter and better suited for scalp application.

Advanced Tips for Faster Beard Growth

For faster results, some people use higher concentrations of minoxidil — like 10% or even 12%.

The higher the concentration, the more likely it is to leave a sticky film or residue on your face

If you’re applying it during the day and need to go out, stick to 5%

You can apply the stronger version at night and wash it off in the morning

Double Your Results by Combining Both Methods

If you want to maximize your beard growth, the ideal method is:

Boost testosterone levels naturally using proven lifestyle and supplement strategies

Apply topical minoxidil twice daily to stimulate localized hair growth

This two-pronged approach works like building muscle: testosterone builds the foundation, while the exercises (in this case, minoxidil) stimulate the localized growth response.

Summary: The Truth About Growing a Thicker Beard

If you want a thicker beard, it comes down to hormonal optimization and stimulating hair follicles in the right way.

Topical minoxidil works. So does raising your testosterone levels. But you’ll need patience, consistency, and the right combination of methods.

All the resources, supplement recommendations, and product links I mention are available below in the description area. Let me know your results if you try it out, and remember — happy beard growing.

title: Lower Cortisol To Increase Testosterone & Sex Drive In 2025
content:
Today it’s 2025 and I want to talk about one of the most overlooked hormones when it comes to testosterone, sex drive, energy, mood, and even fat loss — and that hormone is cortisol.

Most people focus only on boosting testosterone, which is great.

But what they don’t realize is that cortisol is the OPPOSITE of testosterone. When cortisol goes up, testosterone goes down. Period.

Problems Caused By High Cortisol

When cortisol is chronically elevated, it can lead to a wide range of health issues — especially for men trying to improve performance, build muscle, or increase libido.

Lower sex drive and erection problems

Higher blood sugar and increased risk of diabetes

Elevated blood pressure

Poor quality sleep and insomnia

Sluggish thyroid function

Muscle loss and belly fat accumulation

Anxiety and nervousness

Increased inflammation and chronic pain

Basically, if you’re dealing with low testosterone symptoms, there’s a good chance that your cortisol levels are too high.

Top 5 Ways to Lower Cortisol Naturally

Here are 5 of the most effective, proven ways to reduce cortisol and help optimize testosterone, libido, and overall health.

1. Improve Your Sleep Quality

Sleep is the #1 factor for hormone balance.

If you’re not getting enough deep, restorative sleep, your cortisol will stay elevated — and your testosterone will suffer.

Make sleep a top priority — don’t sacrifice it

Don’t wake up to an alarm — wake up naturally whenever possible

Go to bed at the same time every night

Sleep in a dark, cool, and quiet room

Unplug and relax for at least one hour before bed

Avoid caffeine and late workouts

Take calming supplements before bed – I recommend Deep Sleep Formula

2. Exercise — But Don’t Overdo It

Regular exercise helps lower cortisol… but too much can backfire and increase stress hormones.

Exercise consistently but not excessively

Try to train earlier in the day

Keep sessions moderate in length and intensity

Post-workout, take nutrients that reduce cortisol like glycine, vitamin C, and Stress Cortisol Relief

3. Eat To Stabilize Blood Sugar

Blood sugar spikes and crashes increase cortisol, which leads to more stress and less testosterone.

Eat meals that help maintain stable blood sugar

Reduce processed foods and refined sugars

Include omega-3 fats in your diet for hormone balance

Take supplements that help stabilize blood sugar – my favorite is Blood Sugar Optimizer

4. Eliminate Sources of Stress & Anxiety

Chronic mental stress is one of the biggest cortisol triggers. Start identifying and eliminating what’s draining your mental bandwidth.

Limit news and social media, especially before bed and first thing in the morning

Cut out negative people and toxic environments

Turn off unnecessary phone notifications

Stop worrying about things you can’t control

Use stress-reducing herbs and adaptogens like ProVanax

5. Take Mini Daily Breaks

Instead of waiting for stress to build up, actively lower cortisol throughout the day with short, intentional breaks.

Take a 5-minute break every 60–90 minutes

Practice deep breathing or short meditation

Go for a quick walk to reset your nervous system

Journal about what you’re grateful for

Drink water regularly — dehydration increases cortisol

Final Thoughts: Balance Cortisol to Boost Testosterone

If you want higher testosterone and better sex drive, you need to do more than just boost hormones — you also need to reduce cortisol.

It’s not just about adding things in — sometimes, it’s about removing what’s hurting your body the most.

Lowering cortisol is one of the fastest ways to improve mood, energy, focus, libido, erections, and overall hormone health.

There are a few ways for decreasing your stress - diet, exercise & stress management - all being important lifestyle factors.

Unfortunately, they take lots of time & effort and most people want faster results, with less effort... (especially with stress!)

This is the exact problem I ran into with myself. Because of this, I needed to find something that's easy & works quickly.

Well, the good news is that now you can quickly achieve "healthy stress hormone levels" with ONE simple solution that's easy, convenient & requires NO lifestyle changes...

title: ⚠️ Does Porn Kill Your Sex Drive & Cause ED In 2025
content:
I get asked all sorts of questions from men when it comes to testosterone, sex drive, erectile problems, and sexual performance with women.

And when I dig deeper into the root causes of these issues, one thing consistently shows up in the conversation: porn.

So today, let’s answer the big question — Could watching too much porn be silently lowering your testosterone and sex drive?

Let’s look at what science says and what you can do to reverse the damage and get your performance back.

1. The Dopamine Problem – Why Porn is Addictive

Watching porn triggers massive dopamine spikes in the brain — similar to what happens with drugs like cocaine.

Over time, the brain adapts to this overstimulation, making normal, real-life sex feel less exciting or rewarding.

Studies show excessive porn use leads to dopamine desensitization

This causes users to seek more extreme content for the same “high”

2. Porn-Induced Erectile Dysfunction (PIED)

This is happening more and more — especially in younger men.

They’re not struggling with ED because of age… it’s from too much porn use.

Real-life intimacy doesn’t match the intensity of porn, so the brain has a weaker response

A 2016 study found that more porn = lower sexual satisfaction and weaker erections

3. The Coolidge Effect – Why Porn Makes Real Sex Feel Boring

The Coolidge Effect is an evolutionary survival trait: males are wired to seek novelty and new mates.

That’s why men produce millions of sperm daily — to maximize reproduction opportunities.

Porn tricks the brain into thinking you’re constantly with new partners.

This kills long-term attraction to real partners

It makes actual relationships feel dull, leading to boredom, disconnection, and frustration

4. Does Porn Lower Testosterone?

Short-term: Watching porn can give a brief testosterone boost due to anticipation.

Long-term: Chronic porn use leads to:

Lower baseline testosterone levels

Dopamine burnout and emotional flatness

Increased cortisol (stress hormone)

Higher prolactin, which suppresses both dopamine and testosterone

A 2012 study showed that frequent porn users had lower sexual confidence and motivation.

5. Psychological Side Effects of Chronic Porn Use

In addition to hormone damage, porn can also harm your mental and emotional health:

Increased social anxiety, especially around women

Lower self-esteem due to unrealistic body and performance standards

Less motivation to seek out real relationships or intimacy

Some researchers call it sexual exhaustion — your brain is no longer excited by real sex

How to Reverse the Damage

Now let’s get into the solutions.

If you want to restore testosterone, dopamine, confidence, and libido, you need to start with reducing or quitting porn.

Studies show that quitting porn for just 90 days can dramatically improve:

Confidence and sexual motivation

Desire for real sex and intimacy

Exercise 3–5x a week — especially weight training. Keep sessions 40–60 minutes. Don’t overtrain.

Improve your sleep — this is when your hormones are restored. Prioritize deep, quality rest.

Use natural supplements and herbs to increase testosterone and dopamine. I personally use AlphaViril — it has a 25+ year track record and supports both testosterone and dopamine levels.

Take 500 mg of L-Tyrosine, 2–3x daily on an empty stomach to boost dopamine production.

Your Porn Detox Game Plan

If you watch porn daily, start with a 1-week break

Then go for 2 weeks — take note of how you feel, perform, and think

30 days is a solid milestone

90 days is the best-case scenario for a total brain and hormonal reset

Reducing or quitting porn may be the fastest way to boost your testosterone, dopamine, and sex drive.

You’ll have more energy, better focus, stronger erections, and improved confidence.

title: ☕WARNING: Why Caffeine Is Horrible For Your Health In 2025
content:
Most of you aren’t going to like today’s topic, because in 2025 most people consume daily, the most abused drug on the planet, and that’s caffeine.

And YES, caffeine is a drug. So powerful that Coca-Cola’s original ingredient contained cocaine and they needed a replacement for it and the substitute was and still is, caffeine!

Whether it’s your morning or daily coffee and tea, the usual “energy drinks”, sodas, pre-workout products or dozens of other “energy” stimulatory products contain caffeine.

In fact, most people can’t seem to start the day without getting their “caffeine hit.”

The Problems With Caffeine

The problem with caffeine is that it “burns out” your Central Nervous System and causes numerous, negative changes in your hormones, which ultimately accelerates aging.

The negative changes in hormones are:

An increase in stress hormones, such as cortisol — means more belly fat.

Decrease in testosterone — this means less muscle and lower libido.

Drop in growth hormone & IGF — more fat, accelerated aging.

Decrease in thyroid hormones (T3) — slower metabolism and fat gain.

Drop in adrenal hormones — DHEA, pregnenolone, etc.

Decrease in melatonin — sleep and anti-aging hormone.

Increase in estrogen — breast health problems, gynecomastia (“Man Boobs”), irregular menstruation

Higher blood sugar and insulin insensitivity — more fat, less muscle, etc.

Another major issue is neurological in that it causes issues by decreasing dopamine release and dopamine receptor sensitivity — both are bad because it decreases happiness.

It also causes a decrease in another neurotransmitter, serotonin. This means again, less happiness, more worry, stress, anxiety, and panic.

Other Problems With Caffeine

Other health problems that are non-hormonal:

Oxidative stress and inflammation — related to numerous health problems, aches and pains

PH imbalance (more acidic) — acid reflux, osteoporosis, gut bacterium imbalances

Insomnia & poor sleep (shallow REM sleep) — the cause of too many health problems and hormonal imbalances.

Blood Pressure problems

Honestly, I can go on and on.

My Love/Hate With Caffeine

And trust me when I tell you that when I take a little bit of caffeine, I feel AMAZING. I honestly do. I’m happy, very productive, and just more focused.

But I’ve done so many tests with it and no matter what I do, within a few days my body adapts, I need to increase the dose and my hormones start to change for the worst — as does my sleep.

And people who I’ve tested who habitually consume caffeine daily, for years and years (like most of us) — trust me, they have a lot of health issues.

BUT NOT ONCE, will a doctor say “get off the caffeine, it’s killing you.”

Caffeine IS A Powerful & Addictive Drug

This is because nobody even thinks of caffeine as a drug. And “everybody does it.”

Remember, it is a very potent drug and works in many ways, the same as Cocaine. And both are “natural” and found in “nature.”

But they are not to be consumed in highly concentrated sources as we do in modern society.

Anyway, like I said — I really like how I feel on caffeine, I just don’t like to deal with the negatives – especially the hormonal imbalances.

So, what does this mean?

Because I know right now most people are thinking “umm… no way am I gonna stop my caffeine, I love my coffee, etc., etc.”

The Good News – Natural Alternatives

However, the GOOD NEWS is that there are much safer, healthier, and even better solutions — natural herbs, plant extracts, and amino acids that will help support the healthy energy levels and focus you need, but without any of the negative side effects that I’ve mentioned today.

No crash. No negative hormonal changes.

Plus, they are actually GOOD for your health — body AND especially mind. Better for memory, cognition, and mood.

They actually help improve your hormones and neurotransmitters. They have anti-aging benefits, especially for your mind.

If you still want to have your caffeine products, go ahead… but consider lowering the dose and use much healthier and better solutions.

title: 😡 Does Testosterone Make You Angry & Violent In 2025 ?
content:
Today I want to clear up a common myth about testosterone and aggression.

I recently got an email from a guy using AlphaViril.

He was happy with his results – his testosterone levels were higher, and he felt great.

But his wife was concerned. She noticed he’d been more aggressive lately and worried that higher testosterone might lead to violent behavior, like the infamous “roid rage” seen in steroid users.

So, does more testosterone really make you aggressive?

The answer might surprise you.

The Real Cause of Aggression: It’s Not Testosterone

Many people think testosterone makes men violent—but that’s not true.

In fact, new studies show that estrogen is actually the hormone linked to aggression.

Testosterone does increase drive, motivation, and competitiveness, which are good things.

But when testosterone levels rise too high alongside estrogen, that’s when problems can start.

Why Do Some Men Become Aggressive on Steroids?

The aggressive behavior linked to steroid use – often called “roid rage” – isn’t just from testosterone.

Many steroids convert into estrogen in the body.

High estrogen levels lead to mood swings and aggression.

DHT (dihydrotestosterone), another hormone, can increase with steroid use, which may also contribute to irritability.

How Hormones Change As Men Age

As men get older, their hormone balance shifts:

Testosterone levels drop naturally.

Estrogen levels rise due to increased body fat and environmental factors.

DHT levels increase, which can lead to hair loss, prostate growth, and mood issues.

This is why some older men feel more irritable, moody, or aggressive—it’s not from too much testosterone, but from too much estrogen and DHT.

The Ideal Hormone Balance for Men

To feel your best, you want to:

Increase testosterone naturally

Keep estrogen at a moderate level

Prevent excessive DHT buildup

When your hormones are balanced, you’ll experience:

Better muscle growth & fat loss

Higher libido & stronger erections

More motivation & drive

No mood swings or aggression

title: 🥱 Men & Sleep: Dangerous Myth Killing Your Manhood In 2025
content:
Today it’s 2025 and I want to talk about the myth that men don’t need much sleep—you know, the idea that “you can sleep when you’re dead” or that only weak guys need a full night’s rest.

I used to believe this myself. Growing up, I worked long hours, went to school, and barely slept. In medical school, it was almost a badge of honor to brag about how little sleep we got.

Guys would say, “Man, I only slept four hours,” or even, “I didn’t sleep at all last night!”

But now, in my 50s, I realize how wrong that mindset was—especially for men.

Why Sleep Is Essential for Men

Sleep isn’t just about resting. It’s when your body produces key hormones like testosterone and reduces stress hormones like cortisol.

Poor sleep can have a major impact on testosterone levels.

Just a couple of nights of inadequate rest can cause testosterone to drop by 20%–50%.

That’s why men often wake up with morning erections—it’s a sign of a healthy testosterone peak. This is also why libido and performance tend to be better during the day rather than at night.

If you’re not prioritizing sleep, your testosterone will never be at its best. No supplement, workout, or diet can fully make up for the negative effects of chronic sleep deprivation.

Your Testosterone Won’t Improve Without Good Sleep

I’ve talked about testosterone boosters like AlphaViril before, and while they help, they won’t work if you’re not sleeping well.

It’s like going to the gym and eating junk food—you’re sabotaging your progress.

Most guys aren’t sleeping well, and they don’t even realize it. Here are some of the biggest mistakes that hurt testosterone and overall health:

Late-night phone use – Blue light disrupts melatonin production and delays sleep.

Going to bed too late – Deep, restorative sleep happens earlier in the night.

Not allowing enough time in bed – If you want 7 hours of sleep, you need at least 8 hours in bed.

Too much caffeine – Stimulants can affect sleep quality, even if taken earlier in the day.

Late-night workouts – Exercising too late keeps the nervous system overactive, making it harder to relax.

Do Men Need Less Sleep Than Women?

It’s true that most men need less sleep than women. Every girlfriend I’ve had could sleep 9–10 hours, while I personally need about 6–7 hours.

However, I used to push myself on just 5 hours a night, and even though I “functioned,” I was sluggish and unfocused.

When you’re young, you might get away with little sleep, but as you get older, it wrecks your hormones, energy, and focus.

Make Sleep a Priority for Better Health, Hormones, and Sex Drive

Better cognition and focus

Improved mood and energy

Then start prioritizing better sleep.

Watch the full video above to learn exactly how sleep affects your hormones and what you can do to fix it.

I’ve also prepared my best tips, blogs, and videos on optimizing sleep, boosting testosterone, and improving overall health.

Important "Deep Quality Sleep" Shortcut

There are a few ways for improving your sleep - diet, exercise & stress management - all being important lifestyle factors.

Unfortunately, they take lots of time & effort and most people want faster results, with less effort... (especially with sleep!)

This is the exact problem I ran into with myself. Because of this, I needed to find something that's easy & works quickly.

Well, the good news is that now you can quickly achieve "deep quality sleep" with ONE simple solution that's easy, convenient & requires NO lifestyle changes...

title: ⚠️ NOT Having Sex In 2025 ? - 10 Shocking Health Risks
content:
Sex is always a hot topic for most people. Unfortunately, today’s topic is about the top 10 shocking health risks and problems of NOT having sex for a while.

And I bring this up because, in the past few years, there’s been a huge DECLINE in people having sex, especially men.

For example, in men between the ages of 18-24, there’s a 31% increase in reporting “NO sexual activity for the past 12 months”

Also, inactivity has increased by 14% in men between 25-34.

Even with couples who live together, sexual activity has dropped by as much as 23%.

Now, what are the potential causes and the solutions?

I’ll get to that at the end of this article.

But for now, let’s start with the 10 health risks.

By the way, #10 is my favorite because there was an episode of Seinfeld about it. It’s super funny…

10 Health Risks Of Not Having Sex

1. Erectile Dysfunction

As the saying goes, “Use it or lose it”.

That’s right, in a 2008 study in The American Journal of Medicine, abstinence and not having sex, increases the likelihood of erectile dysfunction and impotence.

I’ll give you the reasons for this later.

However, not ejaculating regularly can also cause prostate growth and possibly prostate cancer.

For what it’s worth, the good news is that you can ejaculate on your own – so at least do that 1-2x a week for healthy prostate function.

Not having sex causes erectile problems in men.

In women, some will say that the vagina will get smaller and tighter – which might be a positive benefit for some women and their partners.

Or, the vagina might start to grow cobwebs… which I’m just joking.

However, the truth is that a woman’s pelvic floor muscles will get weaker and atrophy and shrink.

This can lead to bladder problems, urine leakage, and incontinence.

This is a problem in older women and one big reason is the lack of sex and of course, a weaker pelvic floor muscle.

This can be fixed by doing Kegel Exercises. I’ve done a video about this in the past so take a look if you want.

3. No Sex – Lowered Immune System

Not having sex can lower your immune system.

The act of connecting with someone, touching, smelling, and the cardiovascular exercise of having sex all boost your immune system.

Sorry, masturbation doesn’t replace this.

There’s a decrease in libido and sex drive when you don’t have sex for a while.

Something interesting to note is that Sex is not a drive that becomes more and more prominent without it – like hunger.

Sex is a reward system, and when we’re having good sex, we want more good sex.

And the opposite is true… After a while of not having sex, you think about it and crave it less.

This causes a decrease in youth hormones.

Not having sex can for sure cause negative changes in your mood and this affects both men and women, but differently.

For most women, sex is more emotional. They feel most loved and connected. Thus, not having sex can cause them to feel unloved, depressed, anxious, and more stressed.

It’s not just emotional either because when you have sex, there’s a release of “happy” and “bonding” chemicals such as dopamine, serotonin, and oxytocin.

In men, it’s different in that when they don’t have sex, their self-esteem lowers. Their stress hormones such as cortisol also increase, causing them to feel more agitated, short-tempered, and angry.

Nothing makes a man feel important, happy, more giving, and relaxed like sex.

On the flip side, not having sex for a while when you’re in a relationship, can cause insecurities about your relationship. This causes worry, jealousy and anxiety.

6. Lack Of Sex & Decrease In Testosterone

As stated earlier, there can be an increase in stress hormones such as cortisol.

Well, as cortisol levels increase, testosterone levels decrease in both men and women, but especially in men.

When testosterone levels drop, you’ll have less DESIRE to have sex. A lowered libido.

Physically, this can lead to erectile problems in men and vaginal dryness in women.

It’s a negative circle because when you have less desire or you can’t physically perform sexually, then you’ll end up having LESS sex. And less sex further decreases your testosterone levels.

And remember, testosterone is the primary hormone in both men and women, which controls your sexual desire and performance.

7. No Sex – Less Intelligence & Poor Memory

There was an episode of Seinfeld where Elaine stopped having sex with her boyfriend so he could study more and become a doctor.

While at the same time, George stopped having sex with his girlfriend because of a medical thing she was going through.

Well… the outcome was the total opposite.

Elain became dumb and forgetful. While George became much smarter.

So, which is it? Does NOT having sex make you smarter or dumber?

More or less intelligent?

Scientists have demonstrated that sexual activity boosts neuron growth in the brain’s hippocampus.

This means that having sex is good for your brain, as well as your body.

Now, in the case of the episode of Seinfeld, because George couldn’t have sex for a few weeks, his brain was not consumed by sex and it caused him to be more productive – which I find to be accurate.

However, not having sex doesn’t make you more intelligent… as far as the research has shown.

Why Aren’t People Not Having Sex?

So the real question is, why aren’t people not having as much sex?

Well, there are lots of reasons I’m sure. A big one is that most people are consumed by their phones and the internet. So, they aren’t interacting with other people in the real world, in person.

Especially men – who are already not very social compared to women.

Add in all the porn they can consume at their fingertips, anywhere, anytime, any place … and the desire to seek out women, to talk to them, and be intimate has been decreased.

However, there’s another major factor to all of this and that’s the fact that testosterone levels have plummeted over the past few decades. It’s probably half what it used to be just 40-50 years ago.

And, this also affects women too.

YES, testosterone controls sexual desire and performance in both men and women.

And YES, women have more testosterone than they do estrogen… just like men do.

We just have different total amounts of each.

So the point of all of this is that when you have low testosterone, your desire for sex has decreased tremendously. It’s just not on your mind.

And many men also have erectile problems. So, even IF they do want to have sex, they are worried and concerned about their ability to perform sexually. To get an erection and maintain it.

So, this further causes men to retract inward and become isolated.

The bottom line is that NOT having regular sex is not healthy for your body and mind.

It’s not good for your self-esteem or your relationship.

And all of this is linked to lowered testosterone levels.

So my suggestion is to naturally maximize your testosterone levels.

Secondly, you need to put yourself out there and start interacting with people. Human contact is very important for health.

Your phone and the internet are NOT a substitute for a human. Use it to keep in touch and maintain relationships. But in person is what causes relationships to grow and create sexual chemistry.

title: ❗ Men & Sex Drive: The Biggest Myth You’ve Been Told In 2025
content:
Today, I want to talk about a huge misconception—the idea that men are always ready for sex, anytime, anywhere.

There’s this belief that we can just flip a switch, get an erection on demand, and perform effortlessly.

But that’s not how it works. In fact, this unrealistic expectation creates a lot of pressure, which actually makes things worse.

Just the other day, a friend of mine told me he broke up with his girlfriend because of sexual performance issues.

She expected him to be “on” whenever she wanted it, and when he wasn’t, she assumed he was either cheating or not attracted to her. That kind of pressure kills a man’s confidence and makes performance anxiety even worse.

The Media Creates Unrealistic Expectations

We’ve all seen it in movies—two people come home from a date, and within seconds, the guy is ready to go. Or in adult films, men seem to get hard instantly and perform like machines.

But let me tell you the truth… even professional adult film stars can’t do it naturally.

When I worked at a gym in Southern California, I met a lot of guys in the adult film industry, and they all told me the same thing:

They use Viagra or injections to stay hard.

They struggle because of cameras, lights, and pressure.

Even the “pros” aren’t always ready—so why should regular guys be?

Why Men’s Sex Drive Changes Over Time

When you’re young (teens & early 20s), your hormones are through the roof, and everything is new and exciting. Getting aroused is easy.

But as you get older, things change:

Testosterone levels drop

Stress increases (work, relationships, responsibilities)

Porn use can desensitize you

Sex usually happens at night—when you’re tired

Male sex drive is at its peak in the morning & early day – when testosterone is highest, making it easier to get aroused.

It’s Time to Break the Myth

Men aren’t robots. We don’t have an “orgasm button” that works on demand. The pressure to perform only makes things worse.

If you’ve ever felt this way, you’re not alone.

title: 📈 280% Increase In Erectile Dysfunction -The Cause For 2025
content:
If you’ve seen my videos in the past, you know I’ve mentioned the different causes of erectile problems in men.

I’ve spoken about hormonal imbalances, such as low testosterone, high estrogen, and cortisol levels… and low dopamine levels.

I’ve spoken about poor blood flow and low nitric oxide levels.

I’ve also mentioned other factors such as high pressure, blood sugar, and inflammation.

However, here’s one I haven’t spoken about in the past and it’s something I saw on The Diary Of A CEO with Steven Barlett.

So, two very important things I want to mention now in 2025, and one of them is what Steven did at the very end of this clip that can actually cause erectile dysfunction that they didn’t mention in the interview.

But, I’ll get to that in a minute…

Oral Health And Erectile Dysfunction

First, the topic is gum disease and oral health.

Most people do not take good care of their teeth. I’ve made a video about this in the past.

But you really need to focus on improving your oral health, especially if you’re a guy and concerned about getting erections…. Or even getting laid to begin with.

Bad bacteria in your mouth, coupled with the inflammation, lowers blood flow and thus, can indirectly cause erectile problems.

As you saw in the video, Dr. Victoria Sampson said men who have periodontal or gum disease are 280% more likely to have erectile dysfunction.

Add in sub-optimal hormone levels, stress, and poor blood flow from aging, and that 280% increase in erectile problems will be much worse

On a similar note, there are many times I speak to guys and they have bad breath.

That may not be gum disease YET… But the bad breath is from bad bacteria. Yes, that’s from poor eating, incorrect gut bacteria and from bad oral hygiene and basically don’t doing a good job of keeping your mouth clean.

Sure, your focus is improving your erections. But, if you have bad breath, you’re not even going to get laid to begin with.

Mouthwash Causes Erectile Dysfunction?

Before I give you some simple solutions, I want to also mention the end of the clip again:

You’ll notice Steven was going to take a swig of mouthwash to kill the bad bacteria in his mouth. You know, he was just joking around.

This is what most people do – take mouthwash to kill bacteria and improve fresh breath.

However, did you know that mouthwash can cause erectile problems?

Yup, I made a video about this years ago. Here’s what the PubMed Study states:

Short-term clinical trials have shown that antibacterial mouthwash depletes oral nitrate-reducing bacteria, and decreases systemic nitric oxide bioavailability.

Nitric Oxide is what causes erections. This is how drugs like Viagra and Cialis work, by increasing nitric oxide levels.

Which apparently, mouthwash can DECREASE.

Additionally, the study revealed that 12% of men using mouthwash developed hypertension and thus, high blood pressure.

And those using mouthwash twice daily had an even higher incidence of hypertension compared to less frequent users.

And if you didn’t know, high blood pressure is linked to erectile problems. In fact, Viagra was originally a blood pressure drug. The SIDE benefit was erections.

So, they took the active ingredient which is Sildenfil in the blood pressure drug called Revatio.

Then, renamed the SAME drug Viagra, rebranded it for Erectile Dysfunction, increased the price of the same drug by 10-fold, and then made billions of dollars.

The bottom line is that mouthwash may not be good for erections or blood pressure.

So, let’s give you some action plans so you can get laid more and have better erections and healthy blood pressure.

Here’s what I do and something you should consider:

Brush your teeth at least twice daily, I do it after every meal. I also use an electric toothbrush for better cleaning.

Then, floss your teeth after brushing, at least twice a day. For sure before bed at night.

Finally, I use a water pick. This stuff is amazing.

Also, don’t rush through it all. Spend at least 2-3 minutes on all of this. Make it a daily habit.

And if you want to improve your erections – these are my favorite solutions. Take a look, then take action, and don’t improve your oral hygiene.

I promise you, if you ignore this simple task, you’ll just make your erections and overall health much worse.

Besides, nobody likes going to the dentist and then finding out you have a stupid cavity, right?

title: Improve Dopamine For Better Sex & Bigger Erections In 2025
content:
Today it’s 2025 I’m going to talk about dopamine and how it relates to your sex drive and erections.

Here’s something most people don’t know.

The excitatory system in animals, including humans, increases drive and libido… Thus, improving your sexual performance and increasing your sex drive.

On the opposite side, the inhibitory system stimulates sexual reward, sedation, and satiety.

Basically, you’re not “hungry” anymore… This kills your sexual drive.

So, if you’re looking for better erections, you need to stimulate the excitatory system and NOT the inhibitory system.

Dopamine: The Core Excitatory System

So, how do you do this?…

Well, the core excitatory system in your brain is the dopamine system.

Which is linked to the hypothalamus and limbic systems, and includes melanocortins (MC), oxytocin (OT), and norepinephrine (NE).

On the opposite side, the inhibitory system contains brain opioids, endocannabinoid (ECB), and serotonin (5-HT) systems that are activated during periods of sexual inhibition and blunt the excitatory system.

This is why inhibitory drugs that increase serotonin, such as SSRI’s like Prozac and similar antidepressant drugs, cause a decrease in libido and your ability to get an erection and achieve an orgasm.

These drugs also negatively affect women’s sexual desire as well.

To keep it simple, drugs that are downers are more inhibitory. Drugs that are uppers are more excitatory.

Testosterone and Sexual Performance

Now, let’s talk about hormones.

In both men and women, testosterone increases dopamine and thus, increases your desire to have sex.

Testosterone also increases the synthesis of Nitric Oxide, which helps improve blood flow to the penis and the clitoris.

For men, this means bigger, fuller, and harder erections.

So, increasing testosterone naturally from within should be your primary goal if you want a higher sex drive and harder erections.

Both because of what testosterone does directly as the primary sex hormone…. But also what testosterone does indirectly with the increase in dopamine, a neurotransmitter.

On the other hand, you want to minimize the inhibitory system, and that means not taking drugs that increase serotonin such as antidepressants.

And also reducing, minimizing, or eliminating marijuana and even alcohol.

These drugs are inhibitory, not stimulatory.

Natural Ways to Boost Testosterone

As far as this first solution of how to increase testosterone levels naturally, from within. I’ve covered this many times before in previous videos.

You can do so with improvements in your lifestyle by eating better, exercising more, improving your sleep, and reducing stress.

If you want faster results, you can take specific herbs that help increase both testosterone and dopamine levels.

The product I’ve been using for 25 years is AlphaViril. It does all of these hormone optimizations and has additional benefits for improving erections.

Increase Dopamine Levels

Now, this is a complex topic because there are 3 variables.

Reduce things that deplete your dopamine.

Increase your sensitivity to dopamine at the receptors.

I’m going to make a detailed video about these 3 factors in a future video soon, so make sure you’re subscribed to my channel so you’ll know when it’s released.

5 Dopamine-Increasing Solutions

[1] Consume the amino acid, L Tyrosine

It’s needed for dopamine production. I take 500 – 1000 mg, 2-3x daily. Do so on an empty stomach.

I take it first thing in the morning and before my workouts. Don’t take it too late in the day as it could cause sleep problems.

Also, another great supplement for improving dopamine levels is Velvet Bean 25% Extract, which contains L-dopa. I take 100 mg, 2x daily or more.

The good news is that this is already found in AlphaViril.

Combined with other testosterone-boosting herbs, it has a very positive synergistic effect on libido and erections.

[2] Make sure you get enough deep-quality sleep

Sleep optimizes all of your youth hormones and neurotransmitters while reducing stress hormones.

If you have to wake up to an alarm, you’re not sleeping enough.

Go to bed earlier. If you have a hard time falling asleep or staying asleep, take natural herbs. I take Deep Sleep Formula every night because it works really well and I don’t wake up groggy.

[3] Exercise daily or at least 3-5x weekly

Lifting weights helps increase both testosterone and dopamine levels.

Plus, you’ll feel more confident with the extra muscle, which is always good for dopamine levels.

[4] Get sunlight and take extra Vitamin D3 and K2

Most people are deficient or have low levels of Vitamin D.

Vitamin D3 is actually a hormone, not a vitamin. It’s very powerful, especially for testosterone and dopamine levels.

I take 1 pill of Perfect Vitamin D&K daily during the summer and 2 pills during the winter.

It also helps boost your immune system and bone density and has so many health benefits.

Remember, take Vit D3 with K2, they work together.
